definitions.definition: a place where you can buy and drink alcoholic and other drinks

examples.text: We arranged to meet in a bar called the Flamingo.
The area is full of restaurants and bars.
The bar staff are very friendly.
It's the island’s only **licensed bar** *(= one that is allowed to sell alcoholic drinks)*.
I found David in the bar of the Red Lion *(= a room in a pub where drinks are served)*.
The hotel has a restaurant, bar and swimming pool.
There were not many people in the bar.
He's been working in a bar called the Anvil.
We could meet at the theatre and have a drink in the bar.

definitions.definition: a place in which a particular kind of food or drink is the main thing that is served

examples.text: a sushi bar
The hotel has a cocktail bar on the top floor.

definitions.definition: a long wide wooden surface where drinks, etc. are served

examples.text: She was sitting at the bar.
He spent the summer working behind the bar at the local pub.
It was so crowded I couldn't get to the bar.
They were chatting at the bar.
I didn't recognize the man who was serving behind the bar.
You can usually find him propping up (= leaning on) the bar of the Queen's Head.

definitions.definition: a piece of something with straight sides

examples.text: a **bar of chocolate/soap **
a **chocolate bar**
a **candy bar**

definitions.definition: a long straight piece of metal or wood. Bars are often used to stop somebody from getting through a space.

examples.text: He smashed the window with an **iron bar**.
The room was small, with bars on the windows.
The windows at street level were fitted with bars.
a five-bar gate *(= one made with five horizontal bars of wood)*

definitions.definition: a long narrow area at the edge of a computer screen that contains links or pull-down menus or displays information about the website or program that you are using

examples.text: His shot hit the bar.

definitions.definition: a band of colour or light

examples.text: Bars of sunlight slanted down from the tall narrow windows.

definitions.definition: a thing that stops somebody from doing something

examples.text: At that time being a woman was a bar to promotion in most professions.

definitions.definition: one of the short sections of equal length that a piece of music is divided into, and the notes that are in it

examples.text: four beats to the bar
the opening bars of a piece of music
She played a few bars on the piano.

phrases: two, four, etc. beats to the bar

definitions.definition: the profession of barrister (= a lawyer in a higher court)

examples.text: to **be called to the Bar** *(= allowed to work as a qualified )*

definitions.definition: the profession of any kind of lawyer
a unit for measuring the pressure of the atmosphere, equal to a hundred thousand newtons per square metre
a piece of metal with wire wrapped around it that becomes red and hot when electricity is passed through it

examples.text: Switch another bar on if you’re cold.
The murderer is now safely behind bars.

definitions.definition: to set a new, lower standard of quality or performance

examples.text: In the current economic climate we may need to lower the bar on quotas.

definitions.definition: to have nothing to do with something

examples.text: If he tries to sell you his car, don't have a bar of it.

definitions.definition: to set a new, higher standard of quality or performance

examples.text: The factory has raised the bar on productivity, food safety and quality.
This latest computer game raises the bar for interface design.
The awards go to people who have truly raised the bar.
Perhaps the new admission requirements raised the bar too high.

definitions.definition: to set a standard of quality or performance

examples.text: The show really sets the bar for artistic invention.
Sofia sets the bar very high for what she expects of herself.

wordOrigin: noun senses 1 to 12 Middle English: from Old French barre (noun), barrer (verb), of unknown origin. noun sense 13 early 20th cent.: from Greek baros ‘weight’.
